sn24.1:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove …
sn24.1:4.3: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.1:4.4: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
sn24.1:5.1: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and refuge.
sn24.1:5.2: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this.
sn24.1:5.3: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
sn24.1:5.4: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn24.1:6.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.1:6.2: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.1:6.6: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.1:6.7: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.1:6.8: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.1:6.10: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.1:6.12: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.1:6.13: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.1:7.6: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.1:7.8: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.1:7.9: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.1:7.11: “That which is seen, heard, thought, cognized, searched, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.1:7.13: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.1:7.15: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.1:7.16: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.1:8.1: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt in these six cases, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
sn24.1:8.2: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
